estimated_calories.range: 200-300 calories per serving (varies by candy type and serving size)
estimated_calories.notes: Calories can vary widely depending on the type of candy (e.g., gummy vs. chocolate). Check the label for specifics.

macronutrient_breakdown.protein: 0-2g (minimal, unless candy contains nuts or dairy)
macronutrient_breakdown.fat: 5-15g (varies; higher in chocolates, lower in gummies or hard candies)
macronutrient_breakdown.notes: Macronutrients are heavily skewed toward sugars and fats with minimal protein.

key_vitamins_and_minerals.notes: Most candies lack meaningful vitamins/minerals. Dark chocolate may contain trace iron/magnesium.

health_benefits.candy: Quick energy boost (from sugars), potential mood elevation (dopamine response)
health_benefits.dark_chocolate: If present, may offer antioxidants (flavonoids) and minor heart health benefits
health_benefits.notes: Benefits are limited and outweighed by high sugar content in most cases.

allergens_dietary_concerns.common_allergens: Dairy (milk chocolate), soy (lecithin), nuts (peanuts, almonds), gluten (some candies)
allergens_dietary_concerns.dietary_concerns: High glycemic index, artificial colors/flavors (potential sensitivities), not suitable for low-sugar diets
allergens_dietary_concerns.notes: Always check the label for allergen warnings.

healthier_recommendations.portion_control: Stick to a small serving (e.g., 1-2 pieces) to limit sugar intake
healthier_recommendations.alternatives: Pair with nuts or fruit for balance, or choose dark chocolate (70%+ cocoa) for less sugar
healthier_recommendations.timing: Consume with a meal to slow sugar absorption
healthier_recommendations.general_advice: Treat candy as an occasional indulgence, not a daily snack.
